commands.description: show detailed app information
commands.help:
show detailed app information

Examples:

 $ heroku apps:info
 === example
 Git URL:   https://git.heroku.com/example.git
 Repo Size: 5M
 ...

 $ heroku apps:info --shell
 git_url=https://git.heroku.com/example.git
 repo_size=5000000
 ...

flags.description: output more shell friendly key/value pairs

commands.description: display the config vars for an app

flags.name: shell
flags.description: output config vars in shell format

flags.name: json
flags.description: output config vars in json format

commands.description: set one or more config vars
commands.help:
Examples:

 $ heroku config:set RAILS_ENV=staging
 Setting config vars and restarting example... done
 RAILS_ENV: staging

 $ heroku config:set RAILS_ENV=staging RACK_ENV=staging
 Setting config vars and restarting example... done
 RAILS_ENV: staging
 RACK_ENV:  staging

commands.description: set one or more config vars
commands.help:
Examples:

 $ heroku config:set RAILS_ENV=staging
 Setting config vars and restarting example... done
 RAILS_ENV: staging

 $ heroku config:set RAILS_ENV=staging RACK_ENV=staging
 Setting config vars and restarting example... done
 RAILS_ENV: staging
 RACK_ENV:  staging

commands.description: display a config value for an app
commands.help:
Example:

 $ heroku config:get RAILS_ENV
 production

flags.name: shell
flags.description: output config var in shell format

commands.description: unset one or more config vars
commands.help:
Examples:

 $ heroku config:unset RAILS_ENV
 Unsetting RAILS_ENV and restarting example... done

 $ heroku config:unset RAILS_ENV RACK_ENV
 Unsetting RAILS_ENV, RACK_ENV and restarting example... done

commands.description: display the current maintenance status of app
take the app out of maintenance mode
put the app into maintenance mode
list dynos for an app
commands.help:
Example:

 $ heroku ps
 === run: one-off dyno
 run.1: up for 5m: bash

 === web: bundle exec thin start -p $PORT
 web.1: created for 30s

commands.help:

 $ heroku stack
 === example Available Stacks
   cedar-10
 * cedar-14

commands.description: add new app buildpack, inserting into list of buildpacks if necessary

 $ heroku buildpacks:add -i 1 https://github.com/heroku/heroku-buildpack-ruby

commands.description: lists your add-ons and attachments
commands.help:
The default filter applied depends on whether you are in a Heroku app
directory. If so, the --app flag is implied. If not, the default of --all
is implied. Explicitly providing either flag overrides the default
behavior.

Examples:

  $ heroku addons --all
  $ heroku addons --app acme-inc-www

Overview of Add-ons:

  Add-ons are created with the `addons:create` command, providing a reference
  to an add-on service (such as `heroku-postgresql`) or a service and plan
  (such as `heroku-postgresql:hobby-dev`).

  At creation, each add-on is given a globally unique name. In addition, each
  add-on has at least one attachment alias to each application which uses the
  add-on. In all cases, the owning application will be attached to the add-on.
  An attachment alias is unique to its application, and is used as a prefix to
  any environment variables it exports to the application.

  In this example, a `heroku-postgresql` add-on is created and its given name
  is `postgresql-deep-6913` with a default attachment alias of `DATABASE`:

    $ heroku addons:create heroku-postgresql --app my-app
    Creating postgresql-deep-6913... done, (free)
    Adding postgresql-deep-6913 to my-app... done
    Setting DATABASE_URL and restarting my-app... done, v5
    Database has been created and is available

    $ heroku addons --app my-app
    Add-on                                     Plan       Price
    ─────────────────────────────────────────  ─────────  ─────
    heroku-postgresql (postgresql-deep-6913)   hobby-dev  free
    └─ as DATABASE

  The add-on name and, in some cases, the attachment alias can be specified by
  the user. For instance, we can add a second database to the app, specifying
  both these identifiers:

    $ heroku addons:create heroku-postgresql --app my-app --name main-db --as PRIMARY_DB
    Creating main-db... done, (free)
    Adding main-db to my-app... done
    Setting PRIMARY_DB_URL and restarting my-app... done, v6
    Database has been created and is available

    $ heroku addons --app my-app
    Add-on                                     Plan       Price
    ─────────────────────────────────────────  ─────────  ─────
    heroku-postgresql (main-db)                hobby-dev  free
    └─ as PRIMARY_DB

    heroku-postgresql (postgresql-deep-6913)   hobby-dev  free
    └─ as DATABASE

  Attachment aliases can also be specified when making attachments:

    $ heroku addons:attach main-db --app my-app --as ANOTHER_NAME
    Attaching main-db as ANOTHER_NAME to my-app... done
    Setting ANOTHER_NAME vars and restarting my-app... done, v7

    $ heroku addons --app my-app
    Add-on                                     Plan       Price
    ─────────────────────────────────────────  ─────────  ─────
    heroku-postgresql (main-db)                hobby-dev  free
    ├─ as PRIMARY_DB
    └─ as ANOTHER_NAME

    heroku-postgresql (postgresql-deep-6913)   hobby-dev  free
    └─ as DATABASE

  For more information, read https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/add-ons.

flags.name: all
flags.description: show add-ons and attachments for all accessible apps

commands.description: Show info about an add-on and its attachments.
Rename an add-on.
Fork an existing app into a new one
commands.help:
Copy config vars and Heroku Postgres data, and re-provision add-ons to a new app.
New app name should not be an existing app. The new app will be created as part of the forking process.

Example:

  $ heroku fork --from my-production-app --to my-development-app

topic.name: git
topic.description: manage local git repository for app

commands.description: adds a git remote to an app repo
commands.help:
extra arguments will be passed to git remote add

Examples:

  $ heroku git:remote -a example set git remote heroku to https://git.heroku.com/example.git

commands.description: clones a heroku app to your local machine at DIRECTORY (defaults to app name)
commands.help:
Examples:

  $ heroku git:clone -a example
  Cloning into 'example'...
  remote: Counting objects: 42, done.
  ...

flags.name: remote
flags.description: the git remote to create, default "heroku"

commands.description: run heroku app locally
commands.help:
Start the application specified by a Procfile (defaults to ./Procfile)

Examples:

  heroku local
  heroku local web
  heroku local -f Procfile.test -e .env.test

commands.description: run a one-off command
commands.help:
Example:

  heroku local:run bin/migrate

commands.description: display forego version
commands.help: Display forego version

topics.name: run
topics.description: run a one-off process inside a Heroku dyno

commands.description: run a one-off process inside a heroku dyno
commands.help:
Examples:

  $ heroku run bash
  Running bash on app... up, run.1
  ~ $

  $ heroku run -s hobby -- myscript.sh -a arg1 -s arg2
  Running myscript.sh -a arg1 -s arg2 on app... up, run.1

flags.name: exit-code
flags.description: passthrough the exit code of the remote command

flags.name: env
flags.description: environment variables to set (use ';' to split multiple vars)

commands.description: Display current status of Heroku Platform
commands.help: Example: heroku status
